timeline.bodyText: Do we really need this new converter? Seems like it would be the subject of another PR.
timeline.author: meltsufin

replies.bodyText:
There is some problem with such "code" converters - no one can overwrite them because of initialization restrictions...
Basically I agree, I'll think about how to improve it better.
replies.author: s13o

timeline.author: meltsufin

timeline.bodyText:
I don't think this class should be abstract, you never use it for inheritance.
Also, it should not be named CommitTimestampSupplier as it does not supply anything.
It seems that CommitTimestampDecorator would be a more appropriate name.
Does it make sense?
timeline.author: dmitry-s

replies.bodyText:
A better name is CommitTimestampConverter.
It should be abstract, yes, I've answered about it in the next comment.
We should mandatory extend it with final sources and target types - otherwise  org.springframework.data.convert.CustomConversions.StoreConversions#getRegistrationFor will not resolve TypeArguments of it.
replies.author: s13o

replies.bodyText: I would prefer to call it a Decorator because it follows the Decorator design pattern (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Decorator_pattern)
replies.author: dmitry-s

timeline.bodyText: Is it really necessary to use anonymous class?
timeline.author: dmitry-s

replies.bodyText:
unfortunately, yes, it is necessary.
Today any Converter should be mandatory a class, not a lambda-function - types of "source" and "target" are resolved from the class as TypeArguments :(
Take a look at org.springframework.data.convert.CustomConversions.StoreConversions#getRegistrationFor
replies.author: s13o
